thread.title: Duel over education-funding plan: Funny meeting you here
thread.title_full: Duel over education-funding plan: Funny meeting you here

author: Political Insider
title: Duel over education-funding plan: Funny meeting you here
text:
When State Treasurer Jeff DeWit heard Arizona’s congressional delegation was meeting with Ducey last week in the Executive Tower, he dashed across the building’s lobby to wait for them to exit the elevators to say hi and provide them with information about his opposition to the gov’s education funding plan.
DeWit, who went public last month with his take-down of the governor’s proposal to tap state trust fund proceeds to boost K-12 funding, said he wanted to present his side of the story and make the congressmen aware of their role in the plan. DeWit contends Ducey’s plan would require Congress to sign off on changes to the 1910 Enabling Act, which allowed Arizona to become a state. (Ducey disagrees.)
When congressional members walked off the elevator after meeting with Ducey, DeWit was there to greet them.
“I figured as long as they’re here, I might as well say hi – it’s not that frequent that they’re all down here like that,” DeWit said. “I thought I might as well send them home with (literature) about my take. You know how busy they are, if I just mail it to their office, I can’t ensure I’ll actually get it into their hands.”
DeWit said the conversations were light-hearted. “I just said, ‘By the way there’s some signs over there that share one side of the issue, here’s something you can read if you want to get put to sleep that shows the other side of the issue.' ”
Earlier this month, Ducey’s office set up nine giant posters touting the ed-funding plan in the Executive Tower lobby. The fact the display was just outside DeWit’s office had nothing to do with it, Ducey’s staff said; they were simply taking advantage of the highly trafficked lobby.
Yvonne Wingett Sanchez Reporter: Yvonne Wingett Sanchez covers the Governor’s Office and state politics with an emphasis on accountability of state officials. She has previously covered Maricopa County, focusing on the years-long infighting that led to a federal grand-jury investigation, as well as Latino Affairs.
